Award.AwardTitle: Chinese Immigration and Family Encounters in Italy

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Dr. Elizabeth L. Krause, University of Massachusetts at Amherst, will conduct qualitative research on how families transform and cope in the context of transnational capitalism and immigration. The Province of Prato (Italy) will serve as an ethnographic laboratory for investigating the conditions of globalization. Here, a historic textile district known for its Made in Italy "brand" hosts one of Europe's largest overseas Chinese communities. The research will examine instances where Chinese workers in the textile industry encounter state officials concerning workplace health and safety conditions; the health and well-being of area residents; and the sending of Chinese children back to China to be cared for by relatives. This research will investigate how family arrangements have shifted as a result of economic, political, and social transformations, thereby illuminating the cultural logics and values that emerge from encounters between workers and state institutions.

The project will involve three types of data collection: 1) structured data elicitation, in the form of tasks such as free lists; 2) semi-structured interviews with Chinese parents who work in the textile industry and who have experience sending their children back to China; and 3) unstructured interviews, in the form of naturally occurring speech at public and other social events, as well as participant observation in work and health environments.

Collaboration with a Prato-based research institute will take place at all levels: research design, data collection, data analysis, writing, and policy-making. A training component focuses on developing systematic approaches to qualitative data analysis, and findings will be disseminated through academic and public outlets. Contributions will also be made to an urban diversity management plan in the Province of Prato. The results of the research will deepen understandings of emerging values and increase the possibilities for well-being in the context of globalization and immigration.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This transnational collaborative project contributes substantial knowledge, training, and interventions to understanding and confronting social dynamics of globalization. The results demonstrate intellectual merit and advance knowledge related to a globalized economy, local politics, and immigrant health. The project investigates how families, individuals, and communities cope with challenges of transnational capitalism.

The method for advancing knowledge was primarily field-based anthropological research. The metropolitan area of Prato, Italy, served as an ethnographic laboratory for investigating specific conditions of globalization. This historic textile district hosts one of Europe's largest overseas Chinese communities. Most of these immigrants produce low-cost items for the fast-fashion industry.

Research findings revealed that value is created through a range of capitalist and non-capitalist activities. The circulation of children and the formation of global households animate networks of reciprocity. The research demonstrated that, even in a hyper-globalized context, money has specific meanings that can be traced to structural encounters between local, regional, and global economic models of development. Struggles over the future of the city involved anthropological interventions for managing diversity and addressing segregation.

Innovation involved designing and implementing an encounter ethnography framework. The Principal Investigator conceived of this methodological approach to guide an investigation of encounters between family members and institutions, particularly those varieties directed at the health and well-being of the migrant body. The team identified key points where Italian institutions and Chinese residents encounter one another, such as when Chinese parents send babies back to China and later encounter mental health and education experts who may be critical of this practice; or when factory raids are conducted in the name of public health and safety; or when local leaders explore or devise interventions related to segregation and integration. The strategy was designed to answer the central research question: How do cultural logics and values persist, collide, or morph in a late capitalist economy anchored in familistic regimes?

A collaborative approach was used to elicit, gather, and perform analysis. The Principal Investigator carried out a plan of research that involved four phases. The first two phases were largely completed before the project was funded: (I) Preliminary Research and Preparation; and (II) Literature Review and Collaborative Networking. Core research activities carried out during the four-year timeframe of the project between 2012-2016 included (III) Data Collection and Data Management; and (IV) Data Coding, Analysis, Writing, and Dissemination.

Data collection consisted of team-based ethnographic research designed to elicit data of three types: 1) semi-structured, in the form of interviews; 2) structured, in the form of free lists; and 3) unstructured, in the form of socially occurring speech and practices at rich, ethnographic encounter sites as well as public events. The PI spent a total of 218 days in the field over the course of seven trips between 2012-2015. A total of 73 individuals consented to participate and were formally involved in the project. A resulting digital audio-recorded dataset includes interviews with Chinese and Italians as well as socially occurring speech of infant checkups with Chinese parents and Italian healthcare workers. Full semi-structured interviews involved 41 digital audio recordings with Chinese immigrant parents (involving 44 individuals). Another 21 Italians also partook in semi-structured interviews, including about a dozen healthcare professionals, educators and others who experienced changes in the textile sector. Audio recordings were transcribed in the interview language: either Wenzhouese, Mandarin, or Italian. Chinese transcriptions were translated into English. Researchers used qualitative data analysis software to perform text analysis: identifying themes, developing codes, and coding text.

Trainings related to findings and methods were offered to healthcare practitioners, researchers, and students. A training to about 30 Italian healthcare professionals focused on flexible families in the global economy (July 2014). A two-day workshop on qualitative data analysis was offered to 16 Italian social science researchers and graduate students (July 2014).

Ethnographic training in methods and theory were offered to three graduate students and three undergraduate students through direct involvement in the project. One graduate student received a supplement grant for a project on difficult heritage and overseas Chinese with a focus on places of value.

The project contributed to broader impacts for the benefit of society especially through urban planning efforts for “diversity management.” Prato has witnessed dramatic changes in its urban, economic, and social fabric. A related public anthropology initiative addressed separation and segregation. Dubbed “Trame di Quartiere,” or Neighborhood Plots, the undertaking took place in two neighborhoods. It built on the team’s network of relations with associations, cultural clubs, schools, and residents. The initiative was funded by the Region of Tuscany to strengthen local capacity to respond to economic crisis and improve the integration of immigrants who live and work in Prato. Neighborhood Plots offered community-based activities to the public, including engaged technologies involving urban walks, social photography, and digital storytelling.
